Exaggerate: The claim may be considered an exaggeration because there is no evidence provided to support the assertion that the WHO coronavirus test was "bad."
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support its assertion that the WHO coronavirus test was "bad."
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the WHO test was unreliable without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the WHO test did not give false positives when similar viruses were present.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide an alternative explanation.
